title: 108_s949
content: The Act titled "Overseas Military Facility Structure Review Act of 2003" establishes a commission. The Commission on the Review of the Overseas Military Facility Structure of the United States is established with 8 members appointed by Senate and House leaders, who must have experience in national security or foreign policy. Appointments must be made within 45 days of the Act's enactment. The Commission on the Review of the Overseas Military Facility Structure of the United States is established with 8 members appointed for life. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and will meet at the call of the Chairman. A majority of members constitute a quorum, and the Commission will select a Chairman and Vice Chairman from among its members. The Commission on the Review of the Overseas Military Facility Structure of the United States is established with 8 members appointed for life. Vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment. The Commission must hold its first meeting within 30 days of all members being appointed and will meet at the call of the Chairman. A majority of members constitute a quorum, and the Commission will select a Chairman and Vice Chairman from among its members. SEC. 3. DUTIES OF COMMISSION. The Commission will conduct a study on the military facility structure of the US overseas, assessing forces needed, examining current facilities and training ranges, and identifying amounts received from foreign countries. The Commission will assess the adequacy of current military basing and training range structures of the United States overseas, consider the closure or realignment of existing facilities, and address any other relevant issues. The report is due by August 30, 2004. The Commission will submit a report to the President and Congress containing findings, conclusions, and recommendations for legislation and administrative actions. Additionally, the report will include a proposal for an overseas basing strategy for the Department of Defense to meet current and future mission requirements. The Commission has powers outlined in Section 4. The Commission, as outlined in Section 4, has the authority to hold hearings, gather information from federal agencies, receive administrative support services, and utilize postal services to carry out its duties under this Act. The Commission, authorized by Section 4, can conduct hearings, gather information from federal agencies, and receive support services. It is also allowed to accept gifts, services, or property. Commission personnel matters are addressed in Section 5. Members of the Commission are compensated based on their status as federal government employees or not. Non-government members receive daily pay equivalent to level IV of the Executive Schedule, while government members serve without additional compensation. Travel expenses are also provided for Commission members. Members and staff of the Commission may receive transportation on Military Airlift Command aircraft for official duties. The Chairman can appoint an executive director and necessary personnel without following civil service laws. The Commission can also hire staff to assist in its duties. The Commission's staff, including an executive director, is limited to 12 members. The Chairman can set compensation without following certain pay regulations. Employees from specific government departments can be detailed to the Commission without reimbursement. Temporary and intermittent services can be procured as needed. The Chairman of the Commission can procure temporary and intermittent services at rates not exceeding the daily equivalent of the annual rate of basic pay for level V of the Executive Schedule. SEC. 6. Security clearances required for Commission members, staff, experts, and consultants. Secretary of Defense responsible for handling national security information. SEC. 7. Commission terminates 45 days after report submission. SEC. 8. $3,000,000 authorized for Commission, available until September 2005.
